By the way guys, one significant difference between your two models is that=
 I believe Jeff's model has knees and Vinod's does not.  Therefore, the res=
ults are not as directly comparable as they appear when just looking at the=
 creature morphologies casually.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Cl=
une <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> > Hi Jeff!
> 
> Hi Vinod. 
> 
> > It is an inte=
resting and useful analysis of HyperNEAT's sensitivity to
> > geometry in t=
he quadruped locomotion domain.  BTW, I will also be
> > presenting a paper=
 that utilizes the same domain at the same GECCO
> > track, and it also has=
 been nominated for the Best Paper Award.  It
> > introduces a new abstract=
ion of indirect encoding for evolving
> > symmetric and modular neural netw=
orks:
> > 
> >    http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/?valsalam:gecco09
> > 
> > So it =
looks like we are going to have an exciting competition for the
> > Best Pa=
per Award :-)
> 
> Congratulations! The paper looks very cool. I wish you t=
he best of luck.
> 
> > -- Table 1, listing the gaits for different leg ord=
erings, is
> >    particularly interesting because it gives insight into th=
e type of
> >    patterns that the CPPN tends to produce. Do you have onlin=
e videos
> >    of the different gaits?
> > 
> > -- What is the phase diffe=
rence between the legs for the gaits with
> >    left-right and front-back =
symmetry (Table 1)?  In particular, do
> >    they qualify as pace and boun=
d respectively, i.e. is the phase
> >    difference between the sides a hal=
f-period? (I usually find it
> >    useful to plot the leg angles as a func=
tion of time to determine
> >    the leg phases more accurately than by obs=
erving the videos.)
> 
> I looked at these videos a while back and found th=
at most of the bilaterally
> symmetric gaits have two of the legs stiff and=
 the other two doing most of
> the work. So, I would not classify those as =
pace and bound. At the moment, I
> do not recall any true pace and bound ga=
its. I will look into that again,
> but at the moment I am swamped with a p=
aper deadline and the end-of-semester
> rush. I don't have any videos poste=
d yet, but I will try to get to that
> before I leave the country (I'm off =
to Norway soon for the Congress on
> Evolutionary Computation).
> 
> I have=
 looked at plots of the angles over time in the past, as in this
> paper:
>=
 
> http://devolab.msu.edu/supportDocs/EvolvingCoordinatedGaitsWithHyperNEA=
T
> 
> I have not yet done that for the gaits in the GECCO paper. It would =
be
> interesting to try.
> 
> By the way, I still plan on using angular vel=
ocities instead of desired
> angles with HyperNEAT. That may produce more n=
atural pace and bound gaits,
> especially when using a geometric representa=
tion that is biased toward
> producing such gaits.
> 
> > -- What kind of g=
aits did the HyperNEAT experiments with randomized
> >    geometry produce?=
  Are they similar to the gaits in Table 1, with
> >    all four legs in sy=
nchrony occurring in the majority of trials?
> 
> If memory serves, the ans=
wer is yes. They mostly produced gaits with all
> four legs in synchrony. I=
'll try to check in on that when I have a sec to
> provide a more definitiv=
e answer.
> 
> > -- In the randomized experiments, do you think keeping the=
 PRYS inputs
> >    fixed and randomizing only the other inputs would produ=
ce better
> >    results?  It seems to me that including the PRYS inputs in=
 the
> >    randomization may disrupt the geometry more since they do not h=
ave
> >    a clear geometric interpretation.
> 
> Interesting. I would thin=
k the opposite. Since they have no proper geometric
> location, why should =
it matter one way or the other if they are included in
> the randomization.=
 In a sense, their current position is random. Why do you
> think HyperNEAT=
 will do better with PRYS where it is than in any other
> random location? =
 
> 
> > -- You mention that each controller was simulated for 6000 time st=
eps,
> >    but the simulation was terminated early if the controller did n=
ot
> >    produce good behavior.  Do such early termination occur during th=
e
> >    evaluation of champions evolved by HyperNEAT as well?  Also, how
>=
 >    long was each time step?
> 
> Those 6000 seconds correspond to 6 seco=
nds of 'real' simulated time. I'm
> nearly sure that the answer to your que=
stion is that some of the HyperNEAT
> champs do not fall over in the time a=
llowed and others do. Another
> interesting question is what happens if I t=
ake the final HyperNEAT champions
> and run them for more than 6 seconds. T=
his would test whether they have
> evolved a true, general gait. I plan on =
performing that study when I put
> these results into a journal article.
> =

> I am sorry I can't provide less qualified answers at the moment, but I
>=
 really am overwhelmed with work. I will try to get you better answers when=

> the storm clears. 
> 
> Congrats again on your best paper nomination. It=
 is fun that we are working
> on different ways of evolving controllers for=
 the same domain.
> 
> Jeff
> 
> > 
> > Thanks!
> > Vinod
> > 
> > 
> > At =
Wed, 15 Apr 2009 20:07:52 -0400,
> > Jeff Clune wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hello all=
-
> >> 
> >> Below is a link to a new HyperNEAT paper that I will present a=
t GECCO 2009
> >> this summer. It studies how sensitive HyperNEAT is to dif=
ferent geometric
> >> representations of the same problem.
> >> 
> >> I am =
especially excited about this paper because it was nominated for the
> >> B=
est Paper Award in the Generative and Developmental Systems track. If you
>=
 >> are going to GECCO this year, and enjoyed the paper, please keep it in =
mind
> >> when casting your ballot.
> >> 
> >> The paper can be viewed here=
:
> >> 
> >> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/webfiles/publications/Clune-HyperN=
EATSensitivity
> >> ToGeometry.pdf
> >> 
> >> Abstract:
> >> 
> >> HyperNEA=
T, a generative encoding for evolving artificial neural networks
> >> (ANNs=
), has the unique and powerful ability to exploit the geometry of a
> >> pr=
oblem (e.g., symmetries) by encoding ANNs as a function of a problem's
> >>=
 geometry. This paper provides the first extensive analysis of the
> >> sen=
sitivity of HyperNEAT to different geometric representations of a
> >> prob=
lem. Understanding how geometric representations affect the quality of
> >>=
 evolved solutions should improve future designs of such representations.
>=
 >> HyperNEAT has been shown to produce coordinated gaits for a simulated
>=
 >> quadruped robot with a specific two-dimensional geometric representatio=
n.
> >> Here, the same problem domain is tested, but with different geometr=
ic
> >> representations of the problem. Overall, experiments show that the =
quality
> >> and kind of solutions produced by HyperNEAT can be substantial=
ly affected by
> >> the geometric representation. HyperNEAT outperforms a d=
irect encoding
> >> control even with randomized geometric representations,=
 but performs even
> >> better when a human engineer designs a representati=
on that reflects the
> >> actual geometry of the robot. Unfortunately, even=
 choices in geometric
> >> layout that seem to be inconsequential a priori =
can significantly affect
> >> fitness. Additionally, a geometric representa=
tion can bias the type of
> >> solutions generated (e.g., make left-right s=
ymmetry more common than
> >> front-back symmetry). The results suggest tha=
t HyperNEAT practitioners can
> >> obtain good results even if they do not =
know how to geometrically represent
> >> a problem, and that further improv=
ements are possible with a well-chosen
> >> geometric representation.
> >> =

> >> 
> >> 
> >> As always, I look forward to any questions or comments yo=
u may have.
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital Evolution=
 Lab, Michigan State University
> >> 
> >> jclune@...
> >>
